explanation:
To check MISRA 'for loop shall be well-formed' for the two for-statements in update_directory we must ensure the second clause uses only the loop counter (and optional boolean flags) and that neither the loop counter nor any object used in the second clause is modified by the loop body (including by functions called from the body). The following symbols are needed:

- languages
  - The for-condition for the outer loop uses languages[language_idx].dirname. We must know the definition, storage duration and mutability of the languages array and its elements to verify the second-clause only depends on the loop counter and that no code in the loop (or called functions) may modify languages or its elements.

- struct Language
  - The type and qualifiers of the dirname member (e.g. const char *dirname) are required to determine whether dirname can be modified by functions called in the loop body and therefore whether the second-clause depends on an object that may be modified by the loop body.

- categories
  - The inner loop condition uses categories[category_idx]. We need the declaration and mutability of the categories array and its elements to confirm they are not modified in the loop body (or by called functions) and thus satisfy MISRA's restriction on the second clause.

- list_directory
  - This function is invoked from the inner loop body. MISRA treats the behaviour of called functions as part of the loop body, so we must inspect list_directory's implementation or contract to ensure it does not modify language_idx, category_idx, the languages or categories arrays (or other objects used in the loop conditions). If it does, the loop would violate the rule.

- update_cached_response
  - Called from error paths inside the loops. We must confirm it does not modify the loop counters or the languages/categories objects used in the loop conditions; if it does, those uses in the for second-clause would be illegal per the rule.

(Other standard library calls used in the loop body such as stat, snprintf, memcpy, free are known to not alter these application globals in normal use; if any non-standard wrapper exists in the project that could alter globals, include those symbols as well.)
